title: Are old people a burden to society? - Quora

response.answer_text: Are old people a burden to society? I don’t believe old people are a burden to society. However, I believe their antiquated ideologies are. Let me explain. Here in the U.S. the older population (Boomers and older) are quite a conservative bunch (with few exceptions). They come from an America that is starkly different than America now. That, if you just work hard, you will become successful and happy. And, to be American means to be patriotic, supporting our troops and military at all costs. That everyone should own a gun or two and damn you for making it more difficult to do so. That healthcare is a privilege not a right, so quit whining. That socialism is equated to communism or fascism. That all immigrants must be legal to live and work in America regardless of their circumstances. That, if you just go to college, work hard, you can later retire with a full pension from a major corporation. This not to mention, they come from a time of the civil rights era where black people were treated like second class citizens and still looked down upon even today.  Now, guess who the largest voter base is in the U.S.? That’s right. The Boomers. They are bringing their antiquated and conservative mindset to the polls, electing conservative officials, conservative Supreme Court judges, and passing conservative legislation. Often reversing progressive bills that had already passed. One step forward, two steps backward. In other words, America remains a bit backwards not because of technology or lack thereof, not because of resources or a lack thereof, but because of backward and antiquated mindsets that are prevalent among the largest voter base in the U.S. Mindsets that do not align with the realities of today’s world. In a sense, I believe old people are what’s holding America back from progressing, and to where it can be. Contrary to what they say, they don’t really want to Make America Great Again (MAGA), but what they really want is to Make America (Like It Was in the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s) Great Again. And, so to this end, yes, I believe old people are a burden to society. But, because it is the right and humane thing to do… us younger generations will continue to care for them and treat them with dignity regardless of their antiquated beliefs. It’s the progressive thing to do.

Are old people a burden to society? Our former President Jimmy Carter continues to build houses for Habitat for Humanity at age 92. He is a compassionate elder who serves as a role model, regardless of political opinion. However, even if an older person is not currently “productive” in material terms or does not serve an inspirational role, they have contributed significantly over their lives, as individuals or as a group, no matter how humble or impressive their status, from the top one percent to the rest of us. Do you really mean “poor” old people who don’t have sufficient resources to meet the cost of living or need medical care? But then, the elderly folks with resources would be just fine. Maybe when elders file their income tax return each year, their fate should be reviewed? Nathaniel Hawthorne wrote “The Scarlet Letter” about A for ADULTERY. B in a neon color on your shirt can stand for BURDEN. Elders have taught and raised the next generation, worked in all ranges of occupations that keep the economy functioning, supported causes and promoted values that enhance quality of life, contributed to the Social Security and Medicare system for five or six decades. Many have invented or been involved in developing useful products, important technology, and scientific processes that have improved and strengthened our way of life, including medical advances and innovative forms of communication. Tremendous hardship and misfortune befall many—entire groups without legal protection have been mistreated, even those that served our country or simply because of their identity. They did not have the opportunity to fulfill their potential, or prove their economic value to society, in large part due to systemic flaws and imbalances. If each person had to justify in dollars their right to live or receive social benefits or continue to be a respected member of society, then what are the criteria, what is the cutoff point, who or what (a death or expusion panel?) would make that determination? So many other groups, in addition to elders, can be arbitrarily determined to be a burden to society, isn’t that a frightening vision of the future. Hitler was the arbiter in his country— he decided that Jews, homosexuals, gypsies, mentally and physically disabled, and other groups were a stain, a burden, on his society. The next step after selecting the inferior group is to marginalize, deprive of rights, spelchek or incarcerate, then DESTROY. Now, in the USA, both immigrants and refugees seeking asylum are added to the list and considered a burden. The line of thinking that would classify entire categories of humanity as burdens—less than human—sickens me.

I’m 74, and my husband is about to turn 78. We may be old but: We still pay taxes. Regularly. Every year. We actually pay quite a bit in taxes. (What I pay in taxes actually exceeds the amount of state pension I’m paid.) After “getting old” we raised one grandchild ourselves, and contributed considerable funds to the raising two others. Now all three are out there working and paying taxes. We do volunteer work. Work that wouldn’t get done otherwise. Or work that someone would have to pay to get done. We still pay for what we consume. Food. Heat. Light. Clothing. Transportation. Occasionally amusements. Our money, it seems, is still welcome in the economy. Some of our friends, of a similar age to us and even older, are still employed in the regular economy. We are a regular source of advice to our children, nieces, nephews, and grandchildren, and occasionally to other younger folk than us who are not related. What to do when the boiler breaks down. Who to call when this or that happens. What is likely to happen if this or that takes place. Should I do this or that. How can I budget for this when I need to buy that. That’s because, by and large, we lived through those same sorts of crises, had to work out who to call, what could be done, who might be helpful, whether choice X or choice Y was better. Lastly, I’d add that there are younger people who are a “burden” to society. For whatever reason, they are not “productive”. But then, maybe they are; it depends on how one defines “burden” and “productive”. The housewife who raised several healthy, happy children to adulthood, looked after her own aged parents and helped keep her husband in employment is not “productive” if all you count is paid employment. But she’s been productive in many, many other ways. The individual who’s had health issues and is not “productive” for that reason may, in fact, be making someone else very happy, or helping out as best he can, but he’s not getting even the minimum wage for it. Children below a certain age are certainly not “productive”, and no doubt there are some who view them as a “burden”. First: define your terms. And then start looking around you.

Q: “Are old people a burden to society?” Yes. Absolutely. But whatcha gonna do? AT one time a hundred years ago, the rich bastards who own this country, literally, were doing a great job of shaping it for the future. They invested in heavy industry and offered jobs. In those days, just about every job could be learned in just a couple of days. They gave it a great transportation system so people could leave their family farms and get those jobs in the city. But some liberal a$$h0le, elected, re-elected, and re-elected again, got the crazy idea that all those children in the factories and all the farms going to waste, and all those widowed, aged grandmas with no way to make a living, needed to be fixed. So he invented Social Security and the Welfare nanny state. Then, a good war came along, and another bunch of liberals invented GI Bills and home loans, and then there were civil rights and voting rights and affirmative action and all that. Now just about everybody is a burden to society. WELL, ACTUALLY, MAYBE NOT. Because, you see, no one is actually PAYING for all those would-be burdens. We have a pretty low tax rate compared to other countries that provide a lot more for their people—for their society. And we sent a lot of people to school. We educated our country. We eradicated diseases. And we kept our farmers in business, so we never lose the land again, like we did back then. When all those liberal Europeans paid those big taxes, they received in return a nation full of very healthy people living in modern homes with good infrastructure, outstanding education, and a great quality of life that even has many paid holidays and paid maternity leave for the first year of a child’s life. But we don’t pay high taxes. So our people aren’t really a burden, they are just accounted for in debt, sold to the highest bidder for fiat money that isn’t backed up by anything. It’s magic! So I take it back. Old people are not a burden to society—they ARE society. And there IS NO BURDEN, because no one is paying high taxes. The same thinking that says “those people are a burden” is the same thinking that makes our nation weak, unhealthy, disabled, uneducated, and fully dependent upon perpetual war to keep the GDP up.

For background: I am 76 coming on 77. There are many heartwarming answers here, answers that I very much agree with. However, we have to reckon on the underlying argument about being a “burden”. Regardless of its origin (state or private pension, or living off savings), old people who do not work for money, or for whom earned income is only, as in my case, a very small fraction of the total are, in effect, using resources that would otherwise be available to those who still work for their income. Medical expenses (whether state-funded or not) also fall unevenly. In those cold financial terms, some of us will be more of a burden than others. Like many other old people, I am blessed with reasonable health; I still contribute in a voluntary capacity to a variety of endeavours; In a word, I am still useful in ways outside those of family loyalty and support. The fact remains, though, that I am spending, using resources, that would be retained by those younger if I was not there. The idea of “burden” seems to have taken hold because of the apparent drain on state support, although private pensions are just as much paid for by others. And are encountering difficulties as the ratio of old to younger people shifts. The problem is one of scale. With the exception of some less honourable people, family and community obligations (for both old people and their younger relatives) were recognised and valued. When things become less personal, it is easy to see why the notion of a “burden” takes hold as the numbers of old people increases. And we will be less than honest if we do not acknowledge that there is a baby-boomer issue here. However well earned, the sight of wealthy retired folk living it up when much younger folk are struggling, struggling and knowing that their retirement will be less cushy, is not calculated to create empathy. I can, for the time being, put some of this behind me: I am still doing stuff valued by others; we pass as much wealth as possible down the generations. But I might at any time lose my capacity to contribute in a direct and measurable way. The costs of my care might increase greatly. Within a family, such costs might be regarded as simply a duty and the product of love. When pushed out as a cost spread across society, things look different, especially when the volume increases out of proportion to the working population. I don’t have some kind of “answer”. But those of us who are boomers (I just escape, formally, because born in 1943, same difference), would be being less than straightforward if we did not see that those much younger than us have problems we did not have to face.

Young people think that they will never grow old. It’s a fact. I felt the same way when I was their age. Now, I’m seventy-four. I couldn’t imagine looking the way I do. I couldn’t imagine feeling the way I do. I couldn’t imagine ever losing that blush of youth. I can imagine it now because I’m living it. I don’t feel like a burden to society quite yet. I was rushing around the house doing laundry, making the bed, cleaning the kitchen, paying bills, showering, and getting dressed to go out. I asked my husband, who was helping me do several of these things, if he thought there would ever be a day when we would need help doing all this. He said yes. I don’t want to live into being a burden. I want to go on my own terms. If I don’t have a mind, if I’m in diapers, if I can’t walk, if I can’t talk, if I can’t continue to contribute to society, I want out. One of the posters to this question pointed out how much older people bring to this world. We know a lot more than young people who think they know everything. I have so much more life experience and so much more life knowledge than younger people do. I’ve lived, I am wise, I am smart, I am capable, and I’ve learned how to be wise, smart and capable in an way that younger people can’t even comprehend. Look carefully over your shoulder, Mr. Questioner. Before you know it, someone younger than you will be asking you the same question. When that happens, then you will understand why the answer is no.

"These are people, our brothers and sisters; maybe their life is unproductive, but productivity is not a justification for killing(…) If all unproductive people may thus be violently eliminated, then woe betide our brave soldiers who return home, wounded, maimed or sick." Cardinal Clemens von Galen ( Mar 16, 1878 - Mar 22, 1946): Sermon of 3 August 1941 Aktion T4 was a postwar name for mass murder by involuntary euthanasia in Nazi Germany. The name T4 is an abbreviation of Tiergartenstraße 4, a street address of the Chancellery department set up in early 1940, in the Berlin borough of Tiergarten, which recruited and paid personnel associated with T4. Certain German physicians were authorised to select patients "deemed incurably sick, after most critical medical examination" and then administer to them a "mercy death." Hitler's order for the "Aktion T4" Euthanasia Programme was dated 1 September 1939. From 1939, the regime began its program of euthanasia, under which those deemed "racially unfit" were to be "euthanised". The senile, the mentally handicapped and mentally ill, epileptics, cripples, children with Down's Syndrome and people with similar afflictions were all to be killed. The killings took place from September 1939 until the end of the war in 1945. The number of victims was originally recorded as 70,273 but this number has been increased by the discovery of victims listed in the archives of the former East Germany. Among those murdered was a cousin of the young Joseph Ratzinger, future Pope Benedict XVI. Church leaders who opposed it – chiefly the Catholic Bishop Clemens August von Galen of Münster and Protestant Bishop Theophil Wurm – were therefore able to rouse widespread public opposition. Galen's three powerful sermons of July and August 1941 earned him the nickname of the "Lion of Münster". The sermons were printed and distributed illegally. Hitler wanted to have Galen removed as a bishop, but Goebbels told him this would result in the loss of the loyalty of Westphalia. The sermons protested against Nazi policies on Gestapo terror, euthanasia, forced sterilization, and concentration camps. His attacks on the Nazis were so severe that Nazi official Walter Tiessler proposed in a letter to Martin Bormann that the Bishop be executed. On 3 August 1941, Cardinal von Galen's third sermon described the continued desecration of Catholic churches, the closing of convents and monasteries, and the deportation of mentally ill people to undisclosed destinations, while a notice was sent to family members stating that the person in question had died. This is murder, he exclaimed, unlawful by divine and German law, a rejection of the laws of God. Cardinal von Galen stated in his sermon, “No, these are not the reasons why these unfortunate patients are to be put to death. It is simply because that according to some doctor, or because of the decision of some committee, they have no longer a right to live because they are ‘unproductive citizens’. The opinion is that since they can no longer make money, they are obsolete machines, comparable with some old cow that can no longer give milk or some horse that has gone lame. What is the lot of unproductive machines and cattle? They are destroyed (…)Once admit the right to kill unproductive persons . . . then none of us can be sure of his life. “ He said he had forwarded his evidence to the State Attorney. If that were indeed a justification for execution, he reasoned, everybody would have to be afraid to even go to a doctor for fear of what might be discovered. The social fabric would be affected. Galen then remarked that a regime which can do away with the Fifth Commandment ("Thou shalt not murder.") can destroy the other commandments as well. Galen went on to raise the question of whether permanently injured German soldiers would fall under the programme as well. Thousands of copies of the sermons were circulated throughout Germany. The resulting local protests in Germany broke the secrecy that had surrounded the euthanasia programme. An English translation of Cardinal von Galen’s 3 August 1941 sermon may be found at: https://www.regent.edu/acad/schedu/uselesseaters/sermon.html

Old people ARE society just as much as anyone else. Don’t try to lock us out of the loop! We mean to stay right here where we belong just as much as anyone else until we’re dead and don’t belong here anymore. If an individual chooses to die because their idea of living is not what they are experiencing, they can “do something” about it, if they wish. But that is their call, no one else has the right to do it for them. There will always be people with a calling for care giving. They WANT Infants, Indigents, Invalids, and the Infirm to care for, wash, feed, comfort. Their heart needs, even requires, these people for its fondest expression. Where would Florence Nightingale have been without them? and Clara Barton? and…wait for it…Mother Teresa—and, for that matter, my Dear Cousin, Doreen, in Orange County, who has done nothing but care for ailing and dependent members of her family her entire life, with nary a whimper of complaint. Every living thing on this Earth has intrinsic value. Humans, unlike most animals, have the ability and the moral imperative to preserve and protect the people who birthed them, nurtured, raised and praised them. Someone else’s father or mother becomes your father or mother when they are in need of a helping hand. … Don’t be stingy with your love and compassion. Give where it’s needed most—that’s what it’s for, Silly Goose!

My grandmother’s mother lived with her daughter (my grandmother) until she died at 85.  (Credit- UNFPR Myanmar) She never worked. She was a wife of a very rich land merchant in unpartitioned India. When borders were set in papers, she, her husband and a preteen daughter were clueless. They were to pack all they could and leave, or get killed. They chose former. They packed whatever they could and somehow managed to stay alive and came to Gurgaon, Haryana in India. She was uneducated but understood the power of education. She encouraged her daughter to study hard, which she did and ended up being a professor after securing two masters. She supported her daughter by taking care of her kids, while grandmother studied and then worked. She helped my grandmother a great deal in managing the house. She ensured that my father and his siblings go to school and study. She filled the void and emptiness of the house. She was full of love and warmth for everyone in the family. Although she went from riches to being nothing almost overnight but it never frustrated her. In fact, she stopped being materialistic after that lesson. Even when she could do very little of physical work, she would chop vegetables, sew clothes, massage her grandchildren and great grandchildren, feed the little ones, received guests. She did everything she could in her power. Even when my father got married and all his siblings did- she went to stay with all her grandchildren for a couple of weeks every year. She spoiled us and even at the age of 70, preferred to cook and of course, we preferred her cooking over anything in the world. There were more family gatherings when she was alive. Life was more alive with her. She was home. Home was her. She died and left a void that none could fill. My father is almost 63 but still feels that something is amiss. No, old people aren’t burden. Old people are the bases of any family. They are to be respected and treasured for the world would be so restless without old people.

Yes, but no more than anyone else. Are children a burden on society? Also, yes. Are college students a burden on society? Yes. Are adults who work full time a burden on society. Still, yes. Did that last one throw you a bit? A working adult is spending time outside of the house, using fossil fueled transportation to get to and from work, not caring for their children while they are at work, not exercising while they are at work, not caring for the elderly while they are at work… Everyone is a burden on society. Even the pre-born are sometimes the cause of loss of productivity because their mom’s have to take time off work to make a human being. Your entire childhood is a burden on society. At what age did you become a productive adult? I know people in their 80’s who still go to work every week. Maybe not a full time job, but a job nonetheless. Are they a burden or are they being productive? I ask this because the 80 year old who doesn’t want to retire is not vacating their position for someone younger to take over. Who is the burden in that case, the 80 year old or the young unemployed person? I’ve also seen plenty of adults in their prime years living on the streets and sucking up tax resources as homelessness is a huge handicap in becoming a productive member of society. I would ask the questioner, are you a burden on society?

Society is a concept we invented and adjusted to serve the interest of the system so in that regard, yes: all babies, children, staying at home mothers, unemployed people, sick people, old people are “a burden” since they don’t contribute to their government’s accounts. If that’s your limited view on the meaning of human life, what they produce and what financial resources you can extract from them, then your answer is yes. Otherwise, the old people are the most precious source of wisdom you will ever find, if you are ever willing to look outside your small box. They are a fascinating living history, the product of another era that created this one we are seeing now. You can’t get close to life itself than observing blooming and fading flowers, leaves, seasons: blooming and fading life, creating the next life. The smiles of elderlies and the smiles of babies are the same smile, same life in various stages - same soul in a brand new or worn out shell, hands that grew up to be used, eyes that got week because they have seen things. While we are born looking very similar, every face of an elderly person tells a very different story, moments of sadness, happiness, obstacles to overcome, fights that were fought - it’s something magical about it.

The following event occurred during a Sunday morning church worship service. The pews were full since it was Grandparents Day. The opening prayer, a couple of songs, and the reading of the scripture are complete. The pastor spoke about the contributions that the grandparents gave our church, the community, and their families. He asks the seniors stand for acknowledgment. The senior citizens are standing. There is that quiet fleeting moment when you can hear a pin drop. Suddenly, there is the clear piping voice of a little three-year-old child, “aren’t you going to stand up, mommy?” The church roars with laughter. The seniors are laughing the most! They laugh until tears are rolling down their cheeks. “Old” or “senior” is a matter of perception. [To let you in on the joke, please note that both mother and child were known to the church family. The mother of the child was twenty-two years old.]

So, the short answer is yes, old people are a burden to society. The longer answer is that “old people” is just a subset of “people”—an entirely subjectively drawn subset I should add—and since what is true of the larger group must be true of any subsets, what is true of people is still true when they become old people and people in general are the biggest burden imaginable on society. This all seems counter-intuitive because people create(-d) society for their own protection, advancement, and to better provide for all of their own needs (including any special needs which might develop in old age). Yet, not only do people resent society’s demand that those same people at least tolerate other people including the people who happen to be older than they are, but people usually resent and dislike society as a whole. And it gets worse: People not only dislike society, but they tend to believe that society actually dislikes them as well, even on an individual basis. In the end then, people are doomed to suffer one another in the thing which they themselves have constructed to provide for the betterment of all. Just thank God that you and I are not people… hmmmm… wait a second…

If by that you mean something like, “Should we get rid of old people?”, then I’ll say, hands off! My parents still give me emotional support and guidance, and I want them around as long as possible, even if I have to change their diapers one day. They also give guidance to many other youths. I like hanging around the elderly more than hanging around people my age. The insight they provide is so interesting. They offer a window into completely different times, offer perspective to my own life, and gift me with lots and lots of tips.
